## Generalized Motor Programs {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Generalized Motor Program (GMP)**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: An **abstract representation of a movement pattern** that can be adapted to various situations by adjusting parameters.
:::

## GMP: Schemas {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Schema**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: A **broad "knowledge structure"** formed through repeated experiences, allowing flexible adaptation to new situations.
:::

## GMP: Variable Practice {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Variable Practice**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Practice that leads to **better skill transfer** compared to consistent practice by forming a more stable "average" representation.
:::

## GMP: Adaptability {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **GMP Adaptability**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: GMPs are **abstract representations of movement patterns adaptable to specific tasks**.
:::

## Dynamical Systems Theory {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Dynamical Systems Theory**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Emphasizes **self-organization, stability, and phase transitions** in motor control, where movement patterns emerge from interactions between the body, environment, and task.
:::

## Dynamical Systems: Attractor {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Attractor**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: A **stable, preferred state** that a system naturally gravitates toward in Dynamical Systems Theory.
:::

## Dynamical Systems: Nonlinearity {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Nonlinearity**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Simple equations can lead to complex events because **nonlinear equations can result in unpredictable outcomes**.
:::

## Dynamical Systems: Coordination {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Coordination**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Coordination of movements can reorganize under **changing constraints**, as demonstrated by the two-finger oscillation task.
:::

## Dynamical Systems: HKB Equation {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Haken–Kelso–Bunz (HKB) Equation**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Describes the **regime of the two-finger oscillation task**.
:::

## Dynamical Systems: Applications {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Applications of Dynamical Systems**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: In practical settings like cardiac health and gait analysis, Dynamical Systems Theory is applied by analyzing **fluctuations of time intervals between events**.
:::

## Dynamical Systems: Focus {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Focus of Dynamical Systems Theory**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Focuses on **self-organizing principles, stability, and phase transitions**.
:::

## Optimization Theory {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Optimization Theory**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: The central theme is that the motor system seeks the most **cost-effective solution**.
:::

## Optimization: Criterion {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Optimization Criterion**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: An example is **minimizing movement time**.
:::

## Optimization: Minimum Jerk {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Minimum Jerk Principle**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Predicts that movements will be **graceful and curved**.
:::

## Optimization: Fitts' Task {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Fitts' Aiming Task**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Illustrates the trade-off between **movement speed and accuracy**.
:::

## Optimization: Challenge {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Challenge for Optimization Theory**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Determining **exactly which variable(s) the motor system is trying to "optimize"**.
:::

## Optimization: Parsimony {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Parsimony**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Keeping theories **as simple as possible**.
:::

## Optimization: Keyframes {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Keyframes**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: **Goal postures** in motor control.
:::

## Optimization: Simulations {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Simulations in Optimization Theory**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Demonstrate that subtle modifications can evoke **significant and adaptive changes in movement**.
:::

## Optimization: Adaptation {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Adaptation in Optimization Theory**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: The motor system optimizes variables and adapts to **different task demands and constraints**.
:::

## Integration of Theories {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Integration of Motor Control Theories**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: A coach might integrate all three motor control theories by using **GMP to adapt skills, Dynamical Systems to guide through movement patterns, and Optimization Theory to train for efficiency**.
:::

## Theories: Adaptability {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Adaptability of Movements**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Generalized Motor Programs theory explains the adaptability of movements via **abstract templates**.
:::

## Theories: Self-Organization {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Self-Organization**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Dynamical Systems Theory emphasizes **self-organization** aspect of motor control.
:::

## Theories: Problem-Solver {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Motor System as a Problem-Solver**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Optimization Theory models the motor system as a **cost-balancing problem-solver**.
:::

## Theories: Factor Analysis {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Factor Analysis**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: A statistical technique that lets one **isolate factors that account for differences among correlations**.
:::

## Theories: Motor Abilities {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Motor Abilities**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Rapid precise movements must be made with **relatively large body segments**, as in driving a golf ball.
:::

## Theories: Hand-Arm Steadiness {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Arm-Hand Steadiness**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: **Unwanted movements of the upper extremity must be eliminated**, as in rifle.
:::

## Theories: Variable vs. Consistent Practice {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Variable Practice vs. Consistent Practice**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: Variable practice is **better than consistent practice**.
:::

## Theories: Task Average {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Task Average**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: One would be accorded to GMP theory because the task average was **centered on 2 rather than 3**.
:::

## Theories: Degrees of Freedom {.flashcard}

::: {.flashcard-front}
Term: **Degrees of Freedom**
:::

::: {.flashcard-back}
Definition: The theory allows for those other criteria, for example, an important criterion may be **minimizing rotation of joints that have costly motion costs**.
:::
